article: Eating 100 Grams of Protein per Day: Meal Prep & Tips
intro: Whether you’re trying to bulk up or slim down, incorporating more protein-rich meals into your diet is a great way to get healthier and meet your fitness goals. 100 grams of protein may seem like a lot to fit into your daily diet, but with a little planning, it’s simple! We’ve developed a handy guide to incorporating more protein into your diet, including sample meal plans for vegans and carnivores alike. Check it out below.

steps.title: Use apps to track your protein intake.
steps.subtitle: and  are 2 examples of food diary apps that can help you keep track of your protein as well as other nutrients. You can also use these apps to record your daily physical activity and manage your weight and muscle gain.
sub-points: These apps are especially convenient when you plan your meals in advance: you can input the meal information into the apps ahead of time so you know exactly how much of each nutrient you’re getting throughout the day.

can be incredibly useful for helping you meet your fitness or weight loss goals, but keep in mind that while these apps may accurately reflect the nutritional content of prepackaged food or fast food, they’re not always accurate when it comes to meals you’ve made at home.
Furthermore, if you struggle with an eating disorder, these apps (particularly their calorie counter) can be triggering and ultimately unhelpful.

steps.title: Snacks
steps.subtitle: If you snack twice a day, try to get about 12 grams of protein in each snack to stay on track. Stock up on protein-rich goodies from the store, like granola bars and shakes. There are also plenty of snacks you can easily make at home.
sub-points: A few pieces of turkey jerky, a chunk of cheese, or couple of boiled eggs can give you a quick protein boost. Boiled eggs also make a simple protein-rich snack:  in advance so you can have a snack ready to go for the next couple of days.
using fresh or frozen berries, Greek yogurt, cashews, coconut water, shredded coconut, and cacao nibs.

Try chia seed pudding: this one takes a little extra prep, but it’s super simple and worth the extra time. Steep some chia seeds overnight in your plant-based milk of choice (like almond milk or cashew milk). It’ll form a thick pudding. In the morning, stir in fruit and, if you want, a sweetener such as honey or agave.
Short on time? Grab a handful of almonds or a big scoop of peanut butter to fill you up between meals or after a workout.

points.name: How much protein do you need?

steps.title: How much protein you need depends on your body and your fitness goals.
steps.subtitle: The minimum RDA (Recommended Dietary Allowance) is .08 grams per kilogram of body weight. However, your age will determine exactly how much protein you need, as will your amount of physical activity each day. Generally, try to make sure that 10-35% of your daily calorie intake comes from protein. For a 2000-calorie diet, that equates to about 50-175 grams of protein a day.
sub-points: Most sedentary adults below the age of 40 need about 46-56 grams of protein every day. People above the age of 40 need about 75-90 grams.
Active adults need about 1.1-1.5 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight every day. So if you’re 200 lbs (91 kg), for instance, you need about 100-136 grams of protein.
Avoid getting too much protein, as many protein-rich foods are high in cholesterol and calories. Additionally, be sure you’re getting enough carbs and fats; protein alone can lead to malnutrition.
